org.strongback.command

Class CommandGroup

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.strongback.command.Command
      • org.strongback.command.CommandGroup

  • @NotThreadSafe
public class CommandGroup
extends Command
    A CommandGroup is a series of Commands executed in sequence or in parallel. A command group is created by extending CommandGroup, and then specifying in the constructor of the subclass whether the Commands should be executed sequential or simultaneously. The commands passed into these methods can be any Command subclass, CommandGroup subclass, or a group of sequential, simultaneous, or forked commands.

    Commands executed one after the other are sequential, and are defined with a call to sequentially(Command...) and the list of Command instances, in order. The whole block finishes only when the last Command is done.

    Commands executed at the same time (in parallel) are simultaneous, and are defined with a call to simultaneously(Command...) and a list of the Command instances. Order is not important, as they are all are executed at the same time. The whole block finishes only when all Commands have completed.

    When a command is to be executed completely independently of the command group, then that command (or group of commands) can be forked. A command (or group) is forked by calling fork(Command) with the one Command, a CommandGroup subclass, or a group created with sequentially(Command...) or simultaneously(Command...). For the purposes of sequentially(Command...) the block finishes instantly.

    Sequential example

    The following code shows a complete CommandGroup subclass that, when executed, first executes a CommandA, then a CommandB, and then finally a CommandC: 

     public class MySequentialCommands extends CommandGroup {
     public MySequentialCommands() {
         sequentially(new CommandA(), new CommandB(), new CommandC());
     }
 }
    The MySequentialCommands will complete when CommandC instance completes.

    Simultaneous example

    The following code shows a complete CommandGroup subclass that, when executed, executes three commands (a CommandA, a CommandB, and a CommandC) all at the same time: 

     public class MySimultaneousCommands extends CommandGroup {
     public MySimultaneousCommands() {
         simultaneously(new CommandA(), new CommandB(), new CommandC());
     }
 }
    The MySimultaneousCommands will complete when the last of the three commands completes.

    Mixture of sequential and simultaneous

    The following code shows a complete CommandGroup subclass that, when executed, executes two commands (a CommandA and a CommandB) at the same time and after both are finished a third command, CommandC: 

     public class MyMixedCommands extends CommandGroup {
     public MyMixedCommands() {
         sequentially(simultaneously(new CommandA(), new CommandB()), new CommandC());
     }
 }
    The MyMixedCommands will complete when the last of the three commands (CommandC) completes.

    Complex example

    The following code shows a complete but more complex CommandGroup subclass that, when executed, first executes CommandA, then executes CommandB, then forks off CommandC and immediately executes CommandD, and finally executes both CommandE and CommandF in parallel: 

     public class MyForkCommands extends CommandGroup {
     public MyForkCommands() {
         sequentially(new CommandA(),
                      new CommandB(),
                      fork(new Command C()),
                      new CommandD());
                      new sequentially( new CommandE(), new CommandF()));
     }
 }
    The MyForkCommands will complete when the last of the two final commands (CommandE or CommandF) completes. Note that this is true even if CommandC is still running.

      • CommandGroup

        protected CommandGroup()
        Create a new command group. Typically, subclass constructors call this constructor (perhaps implicitly) and then add one or more commands using fork(Command), sequentially(Command...), and simultaneously(Command...) .
